While the harp is one of the oldest known stringed instruments, there is evidence of other stringed instruments that are potentially older or have a similar age. Some examples include the following:

1. Lyre: The lyre is another ancient stringed instrument and is considered to have originated around the same time or even earlier than the harp, in Mesopotamia around 3000 BCE. The lyre consists of a soundbox, two arms, and a crossbar, with strings stretched between the crossbar and the soundbox. It was widely used in ancient Mesopotamia, Greece, and Rome and was an important instrument in various religious and cultural practices.
2. Musical bow: The musical bow is a simple stringed instrument that may predate both the harp and the lyre. It consists of a flexible, curved piece of wood or reed with a single string stretched between its ends. The musical bow is played either by plucking the string or striking it with a small stick. There is no definitive date for the origin of the musical bow, but it is believed to have been used by ancient hunter-gatherer societies in Africa, South America, and other parts of the world. It is still played today in some traditional cultures.

While these stringed instruments may be older or have a similar age to the harp, it is challenging to determine their exact origins due to the scarcity of surviving artifacts and the lack of written records from the time. However, it is clear that stringed instruments have a rich and diverse history that spans thousands of years and many different cultures.
